verses.text: I will exalt you, LORD, for you have lifted me up and did not allow my enemies to rejoice over me.
verses.comment: This opening verse stresses how God rescues and protects, prefiguring Christ's victory over death—an exaltation that is deeply fulfilled in the resurrection (cf. Acts 2:32, Catholic tradition of Christ's Paschal victory).

verses.text: O LORD my God, I cried out to you, and you healed me.
verses.comment: David's prayerful dependence shows the efficacy of supplication—a hint toward the Catholic practice of intercessory prayer and sacramental healing (cf. James 5:14-16, Anointing of the Sick).

verses.text: LORD, you brought up my soul from Sheol; you restored me to life from among those going down into the pit.
verses.comment: Deliverance from Sheol prefigures Christ's descent into Hades and resurrection. The Catholic liturgy frequently points to this mystery, connecting Old Testament deliverance with Christ's fulfillment (cf. Catechism of the Catholic Church 631).

verses.text: Sing praise to the LORD, you his faithful ones, and give thanks to his holy name.
verses.comment: David calls the 'faithful ones,' (Heb. 'hasidim'), a word later tied to saints. This echoes the Catholic understanding of the communion of saints as a unified chorus of praise.

verses.text: For his anger lasts only a moment, but his favor is for a lifetime. Weeping may last for a night, but joy comes with the morning.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is emphasized over wrath—a concept widely developed in Catholic theology (cf. Lamentations 3:22-23, Divine Mercy teaching).

verses.text: In my prosperity I said, 'I will never be shaken.'
verses.comment: Self-reliance leads to spiritual danger. This verse echoes the Catholic view of humility and gratitude as necessary for spiritual stability, as seen in the teachings on pride and grace.

verses.text: O LORD, by your favor you made my mountain stand strong; but when you hid your face, I was dismayed.
verses.comment: 'Hide your face' alludes to spiritual dryness or desolation—contemplated deeply in Catholic mysticism (cf. St. John of the Cross, 'Dark Night of the Soul').

verses.text: To you, LORD, I called; I sought mercy from the Lord:
verses.comment: Direct plea connects to both personal prayer and liturgical prayers for mercy, as seen in the Kyrie (Lord, have mercy)—a key Catholic liturgical phrase.

verses.text: What profit is there in my death, if I go down to the pit? Will the dust praise you? Will it declare your faithfulness?
verses.comment: Implied hope for life after death. Catholic view develops from this—a lively expectation of resurrection and the 'communion of saints' praising God eternally.

verses.text: Hear, O LORD, and be gracious to me; LORD, be my helper.
verses.comment: The plea for grace resonates with the Catholic emphasis on grace as freely given and necessary for salvation (cf. Eph. 2:8-9).

verses.text: You turned my mourning into dancing; you removed my sackcloth and clothed me with gladness,
verses.comment: Garment imagery alludes to baptismal clothing—Catholic symbolism where mourning is exchanged for resurrection joy (cf. Rom. 6:4, Easter Vigil rite).

verses.text: so that my glory may sing your praise and not be silent. O LORD my God, I will give thanks to you forever.
verses.comment: Thanksgiving 'forever' gestures toward eternal worship. The Catholic Mass (Eucharist means 'thanksgiving') is the foretaste of perpetual praise offered by the Church in heaven and on earth, fulfilling the psalm's vision.
